timeline.bodyText:
This looks silly, but it didn't work like this (example in line 6743 triggered alarm):
<token postag="VB[PZDN]" postag_regexp="yes" inflected="yes">be</token>
timeline.author: udomai
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -6722,14 +6722,26 @@ USA
             </rule>
             <!-- whose .*/DT::word=who's \1::pivots=whose,who's -->
             <rule id="WHOSE_DT" name="whose DT (possessive)">
+                <antipattern><!-- I wonder whose these beautiful flowers on the counter are. -->
+                    <token>whose</token>
+                    <token skip="-1" regexp="yes">this|that|these|those</token>
+                    <token regexp="yes">be|is|are|was|were|been</token>

replies.bodyText: 'be' has the postag VB. Try:  postag="VB[PZDN]?" or  postag="VB.*"
replies.author: MikeUnwalla

replies.bodyText:
VB.* wasn't an option because I didn't want "being" in there.
I've tried your other suggestion, but the result was the same as for postag="VB[PZDN]": If I make the third token of the antipattern <token postag="VB[PZDN]?" postag_regexp="yes" inflected="yes">be</token>, this example triggers the alarm although it shouldn't:
I wonder whose these beautiful flowers on the counter are.
That's why I went with the above solution — it doesn't look very clever, but it does the job. I will check with Christopher later today why that might be!
replies.author: udomai

replies.bodyText: I found the culprit: 't was the disambiguator. "are" is being disambiguated into a NN – at some point, I would like to learn more about the disambiguator.
replies.author: udomai
